{{good article}} {{Infobox college football player | name = Everett Strupper | image = File:Everett Strupper.jpg | image_size=240px | alt = | class=1918, M. E. | caption = | school=Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets | highschool=[[Riverside Military Academy]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1896|7|26}} | birth_place = [[Columbus, Georgia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1950|2|4|1896|7|26}} | death_place = [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]] | pastschools=[[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech]] (1915–1917) | currentposition= [[Halfback (American football)|Halfback]] | height_ft=5 |height_in=7 |weight_lb=148 | highlights= * [[College football national championships in NCAA Division I FBS|National championship]] (1917) * [[Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association|SIAA]] championship (1916, 1917) * Southern championship (1915) * [[College Football All-Southern Team|All-Southern]] ([[1915 College Football All-Southern Team|1915]], [[1916 College Football All-Southern Team|1916]], [[1917 College Football All-Southern Team|1917]]) * Consensus [[All-American]] ([[1917 College Football All-America Team|1917]]) * Tech All-Era Team ([[John Heisman]] Era) * Tech Athletics Hall of Fame (1956) * [[Georgia Sports Hall of Fame]] (1974) |CFBHOF_year= 1972 }} '''George Everett Strupper Jr.''' (July 26, 1896 – February 4, 1950), known variously as "Ev" or "Strup" or "Stroop" was an [[American football]] player. He played [[Halfback (American football)|halfback]] for [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech]] from 1915 to 1917. Strupper overcame [[Hearing impairment|deafness]] resulting from a childhood illness and was selected as an [[All America|All-American]] in 1917. During Strupper's three years playing for Georgia Tech, the team compiled a record of 24–0–2 and outscored its opponents by a combined score of 1,135 to 61. In Georgia Tech's record-setting [[1916 Cumberland vs. Georgia Tech football game|222–0 win]] over [[Cumberland University|Cumberland College]] in 1916, Strupper scored eight [[touchdown]]s. For many years, [[1917 Georgia Tech Golden Tornado football team|1917 Georgia Tech]] was considered the greatest football team the South ever produced. Strupper starred as part of a renowned [[Offensive backfield|backfield]] including also [[Joe Guyon]], [[Judy Harlan]], and [[Albert Hill (American football)|Al Hill]]. Strupper and teammate [[Walker Carpenter]] were the first players from the [[Deep South]] selected for an All-America first team. Sportswriter [[Morgan Blake]] called Strupper "probably the greatest running half-back the South has known."{{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/officialnational09nationa#page/n9/mode/2up |title=Spalding's Official Football Guide |author=Walter Camp |date=1919 |page=57}} Bernie McCarty writes "Strupper ranks among the greatest broken-field gallopers in Southern football history. And he caught and threw [[Forward pass|passes]], [[Return specialist|returned kick]]s, [[Blocking (American football)|block]]ed well, [[Punt (gridiron football)|punted]] and played a bang-up [[Defense (American football)|defensive]] game." He was posthumously inducted into the [[College Football Hall of Fame]] in 1972 and the [[Georgia Sports Hall of Fame]] in 1974. ==Early years== Strupper was born in [[Columbus, Georgia]], in 1896. His parents, G. Everett Strupper, Sr. (born 1872), and Bessie H. (Hatcher) Strupper (born 1875), were both Georgia natives.Census entry for G. Everett Strupper, Sr., and family. Son G. Everett, born July 1896. Census Place: Columbus Ward 2, Muscogee, Georgia; Roll: 214; Page: 5B; Enumeration District: 0087; FHL microfilm: 1240214. Ancestry.com. 1900 United States Federal Census [database on-line]. As of 1910, his father was employed as a manager at a cotton oil company.Census entry for Benjamin Hatcher and family. Strupper's parents were then living in the house of his maternal grandparent. Census Place: Columbus Ward 3, Muscogee, Georgia; Roll: T624_205; Page: 2A; Enumeration District: 0100; FHL microfilm: 1374218. Ancestry.com. 1910 United States Federal Census [database on-line]. Stupper attended [[Riverside Military Academy]] in [[Gainesville, Georgia]].{{cite news |title=Ex-Tech Great Dies Suddenly: Everett Strupper, Member of Unbeaten Teams, Passes in Atlanta |publisher=The Anniston Star (AP wire story) |date=February 5, 1950|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5260686/extech_great_dies_suddenly/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} He was the star of the school's football team in 1913;{{cite news|title=Prep Teams Fight Fierce Tie For Championship of State; Strupper Star of Both Teams|author=Carl Taylor|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|date=November 16, 1913|page=9|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5264695/prep_teams_fight_fierce_tie_for/}} and is a member of the school's sports hall of fame.{{cite web|url=http://www.riversidemilitary.com/NetCommunity/SportsHallofFame |accessdate=February 19, 2015 |title=RMA Sports Hall of Fame |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219075224/http://www.riversidemilitary.com/NetCommunity/SportsHallofFame |archivedate=February 19, 2015 |df= }} ==Georgia Tech== Strupper enrolled at the [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] (Georgia Tech) in [[Atlanta]] in 1914. During his freshman year, Strupper became a member of the Georgia Phi chapter of the [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]] Fraternity.Georgia School of Technology "Blue Print," 1918. He was a multi-sport athlete competing for Georgia Tech in [[basketball]], [[American football|football]], and [[track and field]]. In 1914, Strupper played for the freshman football team at Georgia Tech.{{cite news|title=Class Football Starts at Tech|author=Hal Reynolds|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|date=December 13, 1914|page=3|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5264879/class_football_starts_at_tech/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} He then played [[Halfback (gridiron football)|halfback]] for Georgia Tech's varsity football teams under head coach [[John Heisman]] from [[1915 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team|1915]] to [[1917 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team|1917]]. Strupper was deaf, and because of his deafness, he called the signals instead of the team's [[quarterback]]. Strupper was a small man, with his height being stated in varying accounts to be between five-feet seven inches and five-feet, ten inches.{{cite news |title=Rank Southerner Above Many Brilliant Grid Men |publisher=Galveston Daily News |date=1917-11-11}} His coach John Heisman later wrote that Strupper was "but 5 feet 7 inches in height, weighed only 148 pounds stripped." He was sometimes known as "little Everett Strupper." Georgia Tech never lost a game in which Strupper played, compiling three consecutive undefeated seasons from 1915 to 1917. During Strupper's three years playing for Georgia Tech, the team compiled a record of 24–0–2. Only two teams managed a tie – the [[1915 Georgia Bulldogs football team|University of Georgia]] in 1915 and [[1916 Washington and Lee Generals football team|Washington & Lee]] in 1916. In those 26 games, Georgia Tech outscored its opponents by a combined score of 1,135 to 61.{{cite web |title=Everett "Strup" Strupper |publisher=College Football Hall of Fame |url={{College Football HoF/url|id=1281}}}} Georgia Tech coach John Heisman later described Strupper as follows:
"Everett Strupper was a small package of condensed [[lightning]] when you turned him loose in an open field with a ball you wanted delivered somewhere in the neighborhood of the enemy's goal line. He was small, but he was put together like a high-powered [[motor]]. His arms and legs did just what his mind told them to do, and, believe me, his mind worked faster than [[Ty Cobb]]'s when he's running the bases. Dodging and twisting, [[Stiff-arm fend|stiff-arming]] and hipping, he'd run the gauntlet of men big enough, you'd think, to pick him up and spank him, and most of the time, too, he'd get away from them, try as hard as they would."{{cite news |author=John Heisman |title=Heisman Tells Inside Story of Strupper's Play |publisher=Atlanta Constitution |date=1923-11-09}}
[[File:Everett "Strup" Strupper (c. 1917).jpg|thumb|240px|right|Strupper from Georgia Tech archives]] Heisman also said of Strupper "Were I compelled to risk my head on what one absolutely unaided gridster might accomplish, football under arm and facing eleven ferocious opponents, I would rather choose and chance this man on how he might come through the gauntlet than any ball carrier I have ever seen in action."{{cite news|title=Everett Strupper, Tech Immortal, Passes Suddenly|work=Georgia Tech Alumni Magazine, March–April 1950|year=1950|accessdate=May 15, 2016|url=http://issuu.com/gtalumni/docs/1950_28_4/19}} Heisman recalled that, when Strupper first arrived from [[Riverside Military Academy]], Heisman could not imagine Strupper playing on the football team: "Too light for the line, I didn't see how he could play in the backfield, because he wouldn't be able to get the signals. He could have played quarterback fine, but his enunciation wasn't clear enough for him to call the plays." Heisman recalled how Strupper overcame the obstacle posed by his deafness: "He couldn't hear anything but a regular shout. But he could read your lips like a flash. No lad that ever stepped on a football field had keener eyes than Everett had. The enemy found this out the minute he began looking for openings through which to run the ball." He was nominated though not selected for an Associated Press All-Time Southeast 1869–1919 era team.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1242&dat=19690731&id=TkdTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YoYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2604,3160960|newspaper=Kingsport Post|title=U-T Greats On All-Time Southeast Team|date=July 31, 1969}} ===1915 season=== In his sophomore year, Strupper proved to be an all-around athlete. As Heisman told it, Strupper "was a star baseball player, a crack at basketball and the best sprint man we had in the school." Heisman recalled that, despite his small stature, Strupper had a powerful body: "Stripped down in the dressing rooms Everett was a sight to behold. There never was a better set up lad than he; he was a regular [[Apollo]], beautifully muscled and built and coordinating rhythmically in every movement." When Strupper tried out for the team, he noticed that the quarterback would shout the signals every time Strupper was to carry the ball. Realizing the loud signals would be a tip-off to the opposition, Strupper told Heisman, "Coach, those loud signals are absolutely unnecessary. You see when sickness in my kid days brought on this deafness my folks gave me the best instructors obtainable to teach me [[Lip reading|lip-reading]]." Strupper first starred in a game against [[Transylvania Pioneers football|Transylvania]], scoring four touchdowns.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4747949/the_atlanta_constitution/|work=The Atlanta Constitution|page=3|date=October 17, 1915|title=Yellow Jackets Win In A Romp|accessdate=March 27, 2016|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|author=[[Dick Jemison]]}} {{Open access}} He was injured the next week against [[1915 LSU Tigers football team|LSU]], and blamed LSU's [[Phillip Cooper]].{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5156784/the_atlanta_constitution/|work=Atlanta Constitution|title=Jackets Win Over Louisiana 36 to 7; Strupper Injured|page=3|date=October 24, 1915|accessdate=May 4, 2016|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} Tech closed what was then the greatest season in its history with a 7–0 defeat of the [[1915 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn Plainsmen]].{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/4493917/the_atlanta_constitution/|work=Atlanta Constitution|page=9|date=November 26, 1915|title=Yellow Jackets Earn Tie To Football Championship By Defeating Plainsmen|author=[[Dick Jemison]]|accessdate=March 2, 2016|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} To begin the second quarter, Strupper had two key plays, the last of which was the game-deciding touchdown.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3278394/the_tennessean/|work=The Tennessean|title=Georgia Tech Claims S.I.A.A. Championship|date=November 26, 1915|page=8|accessdate=March 27, 2016|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} First he made 20 yards around with a pass from [[Froggie Morrison]][https://smartech.gatech.edu/handle/1853/13188?show=full Blue Print, 1916] before being forced out of bounds. Next was the 19-yard touchdown. Strupper started around left end, then cut back into the center of the field, away from his blockers. He [[juke (football move)|juked]] and eluded "every man on the Auburn team." On the last move Strupper faked right and then dove left underneath the outstretched arms of [[Baby Taylor]] into the endzone.{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=T_OOVK2KJMedgwSXj4KQBg&id=p1g4AQAAIAAJ&dq=%22babe+taylor%22+auburn&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22big+babe+taylor%22 |journal=The Volta Review |pages=102–105 |year=1925 |publisher=Volta Bureau |title=A Lip-Reading Football Star}} At the end of the 1915 season, Strupper received two selections from a composite All-Southern eleven selected by ten sports writers and coaches, including those from [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Nashville]], Atlanta, [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]], [[Chattanooga, Tennessee|Chattanooga]], and [[New Orleans]].{{cite news|newspaper = Atlanta Constitution|title = Composite All-Southern Of Ten Of The Dopesters|author = [[Dick Jemison]]|date = November 30, 1915|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/1924630//|accessdate=March 5, 2015|page=10|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} ===1916 season=== [[File:Everett Strupper (October 1917).jpg|thumb|140px|Ev Strupper]] In [[1916 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football team|1916]], Strupper had a 92-yard punt return for a touchdown on opening day against [[Mercer Bears football|Mercer]].http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/geot/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/71stats.pdf The next week, Strupper led Georgia Tech in a 222–0 victory over [[Cumberland Bulldogs football|Cumberland College]], "the most lopsided game in football history."{{cite news |title=Remember When? Tech Won 222-0 Over Cumberland |publisher=Pacific Stars and Stripes (AP wire story) |date=1959-10-08}} The score (compiled on 32 touchdowns and 30 extra points) broke the old record of a 153–0 set by the [[Michigan Wolverines football|University of Michigan]] in 1912. Strupper scored eight touchdowns in the game, six rushing and two on punt returns.{{cite news |author=Arnie Burdick |title=Touching lots of bases |publisher=Syracuse Herald Journal |date=1974-03-04}} One historic account of the 1916 Cumberland game described Strupper as the "lord high executioner":
"There were many executioners that crisp early-fall Saturday. Halfback G.E. Strupper scored from 20 yards out on Tech's first offensive play and went on to be lord high executioner with eight touchdowns and a conversion for a total of 49 points."
In the first quarter alone, Strupper scored four touchdowns on runs of 20, 10, 60, and 45 yards. Strupper chose to allow others to share in the scoring. With a 42–0 lead midway through the first quarter, Strupper broke clear and could have scored easily, but he intentionally grounded the ball at the one-yard line to allow Georgia Tech tackle J. Cantey Alexander to score the first touchdown of his career.{{cite news |author=Mercer Bailey |title=Tech Beat 222-0, in 1916 Game |publisher=The Ogden Standard-Examiner (AP wire story) |date=1956-10-07}} A teammate later recalled the play as follows:
"Strupper swapped positions with Alexander ... The team didn't want to make it too easy for Cantey, though. The other boys wouldn't block for him or help in any way. As soon as the ball was [[Snap (gridiron football)|snapped]], they ran away from [[Lineman (gridiron football)|the line]] and out of the [[American football plays|play]] completely. Leaving poor Cantey to go it alone. Finally, on [[fourth down]], a bruised and weary Alexander managed to get the ball across while his teammates howled with laughter."{{refn|group="n"|As the score became increasingly lopsided, Strupper was pulled from the game, and substitute halfback Jim Fellers also scored five touchdowns and an extra point.}}
[[File:TechPenn1917.jpg|thumb|280px|Strupper ''(far left, with ball)'' rushing v. Penn.]] The game was eventually halted after just 44 minutes of play. It was said only one newspaper in all of the South neglected to have Strupper on its [[College Football All-Southern Team|All-Southern]] team for 1916.{{Closed access}} {{Cite news |url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/HistArchive/?p_product=EANX&p_theme=ahnp&p_nbid=D60M61RXMTQxMDE2OTI3My4zMjE3MDU6MToxMzoxMzIuMTk4LjUwLjEz&p_action=doc&s_lastnonissuequeryname=16&d_viewref=search&p_queryname=16&p_docnum=1&p_docref=v2:1126154AC3F56D80@EANX-119D01998299B5E0@2421202-119D0199C4008940@7-119D019AF02447A0@Strupper%20Given%20Many%20Honors%20Gets%20Pick%20for%20All%20American%20Team%20and%20Practically%20Unanimous%20All%20Southern |title=Strupper Given Many Honors |last= |first= |date=December 4, 1916 |work=Columbus Ledger |accessdate=}} He ranked third in the nation in scoring, including 16 touchdowns.{{cite news|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1916-12-03/ed-1/seq-17/|title=Georgia Tech and Georgetown Lead|author=George B. Underwood|date=December 3, 1916|page=3|work=The Sun}} ===1917 season=== Strupper also played on the 1917 team then considered the greatest the South ever produced, including one of the greatest backfields. According to the ''[[Times-Picayune]]'', "Strupper, [[Joe Guyon|Guyon]], [[Albert Hill (American football)|Hill]], and [[Judy Harlan|Harlan]] form a backfield with no superiors and few equals in football history".{{cite journal | last=McCarty | first=Bernie | title=Georgia Tech's 1917 backfield, better than the Four Horsemen: Part 2 | volume=1|number=4|date=May 1988|journal=College Football Historical Society Newsletter |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304070443/http://library.la84.org/SportsLibrary/CFHSN/CFHSNv01/CFHSNv01n4h.pdf|archivedate=March 4, 2016 | url=http://library.la84.org/SportsLibrary/CFHSN/CFHSNv01/CFHSNv01n4h.pdf}} Tech gave Vanderbilt its worst loss in school history 83–0. "It was not until 1917 that a Southern team really avenged long-time torment at [[Dan McGugin|McGugin]]'s hands. And it took one of history's top backfields–Joe Guyon, Ev Strupper, Al Hill, and Judy Harlan of Georgia Tech–to do it," writes [[Edwin Pope]].{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/fottballsgreates00pope#page/344/mode/2up|page=344|title=Football's Greatest Coaches|author=Edwin Pope}} The team also defeated the [[1917 Penn Quakers football team|University of Pennsylvania]], then one of the Eastern powers, 41–0.{{cite news |title=Ex-Georgia Tech Star Dead at 57 |publisher=The Charleston Daily Mail |date=1950-02-05}} It was called by one writer "Strupper's finest hour." In a 98–0 win over the [[1917 Carlisle Indians football team|Carlisle Indians]] in 1917, Strupper drew praise for his performance. The ''Atlanta Journal'' wrote:
"Everett Strupper played like a veritable [[demon]]. At one time four Carlisle men pounced on him from all directions, and yet through some superhuman witchery he broke loose and dashed 10 yards further. On another occasion he attempted a wide [[end run]], found that he was completely blocked, then suddenly whirled and ran the other way, gaining something like 25 yards before he was downed."
[[File:1917 Georgia Tech backfield.jpg|thumb|160px|alt=Four football players in uniform prepared to run, standing one behind the other|280px|Tech's 1917 backfield; left to right: Strupper, Harlan, Guyon, and Hill]] Strupper scored five touchdowns against Carlisle, including a 32-yard fumble return for a touchdown.{{refn|group="n"|This was Carlisle's last season before the school closed.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160501004439/http://carlisleindian.dickinson.edu/websites/cchs-carlisle-indian-industrial-school-1879-1918|archivedate=May 1, 2016 |url=http://carlisleindian.dickinson.edu/websites/cchs-carlisle-indian-industrial-school-1879-1918|title=Carlisle Indian Industrial School (1879–1918)}}}} And in a 68–7 win over rival Auburn, Strupper had a 65-yard touchdown run that drew the following praise from the ''Atlanta Journal'':
"It was not the length of the run that featured it was the brilliance of it. After getting through the first line, Stroop was [[Tackle (football move)|tackled]] squarely by two secondary men, and yet he squirmed and jerked loosed from them, only to face the [[Safety (gridiron football position)|safety man]] and another Tiger, coming at him from different angles. Without checking his speed Everett knifed the two men completely, running between them and dashing on to a touchdown."
Remarkably, two Georgia Tech players led the country in touchdowns for the 1917 season. Quarterback [[Albert Hill (American football)|Albert Hill]] was first with 23 touchdowns, and Strupper was second with 20 touchdowns.{{cite news|title=Albert Hill Scores Most Touchdowns for Season: Strupper Was Second|newspaper=The Tri-Weekly Constitution (Atlanta)|date=December 5, 1917|page=14|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5260880/albert_hill_scored_most_touchdowns_for/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} Strupper [[Rush (gridiron football)|rushed]] for some 1,150 yards on a little over 100 [[Carry (gridiron football)|carries]].{{cite journal | last=McCarty | first=Bernie | title=Georgia Tech's 1917 backfield, better than the Four Horsemen: Part 1 | volume=1|number=3|date=February 1988|journal=College Football Historical Society Newsletter | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304120719/http://library.la84.org/SportsLibrary/CFHSN/CFHSNv01/CFHSNv01n3a.pdf|archivedate=March 4, 2016 |url=http://library.la84.org/SportsLibrary/CFHSN/CFHSNv01/CFHSNv01n3a.pdf}} Strupper has been recognized as a consensus first-team player on the [[1917 College Football All-America Team]],{{cite web|title=2014 NCAA Football Records: Consensus All-America Selections|publisher=National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA)|year=2014|accessdate=May 14, 2016|page=4|url=http://fs.ncaa.org/Docs/stats/football_records/2014/Awards.pdf}} having received first-team honors from [[Frank G. Menke|Frank Menke Syndicate]],''ESPN College Football Encyclopedia'', p. 1150 [[Paul Purman]],{{cite news|author=Paul Purman|title=East, West, South Give Stars To The Sentinel All-American Football Team For 1917 Season|work=The Fort Wayne Sentinel|date=November 29, 1917}} and [[Dick Jemison]] of the ''[[Atlanta Constitution]]''.[https://archive.org/stream/officialfootball19181nati#page/n21/mode/2up Spalding's Football Guide] Strupper and team captain [[Walker Carpenter]] were the first players from the [[Deep South]] selected for an All-America first team.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QWv3BlnItIEC&pg=PA142#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Creating the Big Game: John W. Heisman and the Invention of American Football |author=Wiley Lee Umphlett |page=142 |date=1992}} Strupper was named as one of four backs on Georgia Tech's "All-Era" team for the Heisman era covering the years from 1904 to 1919.{{cite web|title=2005 Georgia Tech Football Media Guide|publisher=Georgia Institute of Technology|accessdate=May 17, 2016|url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/geot/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/05-mg-honors.pdf}} ==Military football and coaching== On December 8, 1917, Strupper was elected by his teammates to be the captain of the [[1918 Georgia Tech Golden Tornado football team|1918 Georgia Tech football team]].{{cite news|title=Strupper Heads 1918 Golden Tornado: Everett Strupper Elected To Lead 1918 Tech Eleven|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|date=December 9, 1917|page=3|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5260823/strupper_heads_1918_golden_tornado/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} However, Strupper enlisted in the U. S. Army on August 28, 1918, and was assigned to the First Replacement Regiment at [[Camp Gordon]] in [[Augusta, Georgia]].{{cite news|title=Everett Strupper Is At Camp Gordon|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|date=September 1, 1918|page=3|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5261039/everett_strupper_is_at_camp_gordon/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news|title=Military Football To Fill Vacancy Here|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|date=September 29, 1918|page=3|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5261107/military_football_to_fill_vacancy_here/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} In October 1918, Strupper transferred to [[Camp Hancock (Georgia)|Camp Hancock]] and promoted to the rank of sergeant.{{cite news|title=Atlanta Football Fans Keyed Up Over Contest|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|date=October 24, 1918|page=14|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5261175/atlanta_football_fans_keyed_up_over/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} He played football for Camp Gordon and Camp Hancock teams.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3265199/the_tennessean/|title=Berry Features Camp Hancok's 16 to 6 Victory|page=14|date=November 3, 1918|accessdate=September 21, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news|title=Berry Will Lead Hancock Against Gordon Saturday|newspaper=The Evening News|date=October 29, 1918|page=7|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5261562/berry_will_lead_hancock_against_gordon/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} In November 1918, Camp Gordon played a game in Strupper's home town of [[Columbus, Georgia]], and the locals held "Strupper Day" in his honor.{{cite news|title="Strupper Day" at Columbus|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|date=November 9, 1918|page=9|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5261647/strupper_day_at_columbus/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} In a game for Camp Gordon on December 7, 1918, he had two runs of 80 yards and scored four touchdowns.{{cite news|title=Camp Gordon Beats Johnston, 46 to 0|newspaper=The Atlanta Constitution|date=December 8, 1918|page=3|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5261889/camp_gordon_beats_johnston_46_to_0/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} At the end of the season, he was picked as a second-team halfback on [[Walter Camp]]'s All-America service team.{{cite news|title=How Walter Camp Rates All-America Service Men|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=January 9, 1919|page=8|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5261962/how_walter_camp_rates_allamerica/}} The war ended in November 1918, and Strupper was discharged from the Army on December 20, 1918, as part of the post-war demobilization.Georgia World War I Service Card for George E. Strupper, Jr., born July 26, 1896. Ancestry.com. Georgia, World War I Service Cards, 1917-1919 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: Ancestry.com Operations, Inc., 2013. Original data: Georgia Adjutant General’s Office. World War I Statements of Service Cards. Georgia State Archives, Morrow, Georgia. In August 1919, Strupper accepted a job as the backfield coach for [[Oglethorpe University]].{{cite news|title=Strupper To Coach|newspaper=The Indianapolis Star|date=August 7, 1919|page=20|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5262076/strupper_to_coach/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} He next led the [[Columbus High School (Columbus, Georgia)|Columbus High School]] football team.{{Cite news |url=http://infoweb.newsbank.com/iw-search/we/HistArchive/?p_product=EANX&p_theme=ahnp&p_nbid=A55A56DMMTQxMDIwNTMxNi42ODgyMzM6MToxMzoxMzIuMTk4LjUwLjEz&p_action=doc&s_lastnonissuequeryname=16&d_viewref=search&p_queryname=16&p_docnum=6&p_docref=v2:1126A744DB722B38@EANX-117BF1DA42A56610@2422260-117BF1DB561A37E8@4-117BF1DDE40F8970@%22Strupe%22%20Takes%20Charge%20of%20High%20Football%20Squad%20All-American%20Tech%20Quarter%20Relieves%20Coach%20Crawford%20at%20C |title="Strupe" Takes Charge of High Football Squad |last= |first= |date=October 28, 1919 |work=Columbus Daily Enquirer |accessdate=}} Strupper was an assistant coach under [[Josh Cody]] at [[Mercer Bears football|Mercer]] in 1922.{{cite book |title=Gridiron Glory Days: Football at Mercer, 1892–1942 |author=Robert E. Wilder |page=35 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lUafJmAa9RcC&pg=PA35&lpg=PA35&#v=onepage&q&f=false}} ==Family and later years== Strupper was married in approximately 1920 to his wife, Odelle.1930 Census entry for Everett Strupper, Jr, and Odelle Strupper. His age at time of first marriage shown as 23, but he was unmarried at time of 1920 Census. Census Place: Atlanta, Fulton, Georgia; Roll: 364; Page: 3A; Enumeration District: 0116; Image: 84.0; FHL microfilm: 2340099. Ancestry.com. 1930 United States Federal Census [database on-line]. As of 1921, Strupper was living in [[Columbus, Georgia]], working as a salesman for E. F. Gray.{{cite book|title=Polk's Columbus, GA. City Directory|publisher=R. L. Polk & Co., Inc.|year=1921|page=714|via=[[Ancestry.com]]}} From at least 1925 to 1928, Strupper was living in Columbus with his wife, Odelle, and operating a tire business under the name Everett Strupper, Inc. The business sold Dunlop Tires and also provided vulcanizing, road service, washing, greasing and oil.{{cite book|title=Polk's Columbus and Bibb City, GA. City Directory|publisher=R. L. Polk & Co., Inc.|year=1925|page=637|via=[[Ancestry.com]]}}{{cite book|title=Polk's Columbus (Georgia) City Directory|year=1928|publisher=R. L. Polk & Co., Inc.|page=513|via=[[Ancestry.com]]}}{{cite book|title=Polk's Columbus and Bibb City, GA., City Directory|year=1927|publisher=R. L. Polk & Co., Inc.|page=471|via=[[Ancestry.com]]}} [[File:Big Al - University of Alabama Elephant Mascot.jpg|thumb|150px|Strupper is one source for [[University of Alabama|Alabama]]'s red elephant mascot.]] By 1930, Strupper and his wife, Odelle, had moved to [[Atlanta]] where he was employed as the sales manager for an automobile accessories business. He was also a contributor to the ''Atlanta Journal''. Although there are competing stories as to the origin of the [[University of Alabama traditions#The Elephant|Red Elephant mascot]] for the [[University of Alabama]], some sources have cited a story written by Strupper about an October 1930 football game between Alabama and Mississippi. Strupper wrote: "At the end of the quarter, the earth started to tremble, there was a distant rumble that continued to grow. Some excited fan in the stands bellowed, 'Hold your horses, the elephants are coming,' and out stamped this Alabama varsity."{{cite web|title=Big Al|publisher=University of Alabama|accessdate=May 15, 2016|url=http://www.rolltide.com/sports/c-cheer/spec-rel/big-al.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513023323/http://www.rolltide.com/sports/c-cheer/spec-rel/big-al.html|archivedate=May 13, 2014|df=}} By 1934, he was working as a solicitor for the [[Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company]].{{cite book|title=Greater Atlanta City Directory|year=1934|publisher=Atlanta City Directory Co.|page=1058|via=[[Ancestry.com]]}} He worked with former teammate, [[Pup Phillips]], at Massachusetts Mutual. As of 1941, Strupper was still living in Atlanta and employed by Massachusetts Mutual. His spouse, apparently a second wife, was identified as Frances C. Strupper.{{cite book|title=Greater Atlanta City Directory|year=1941|publisher=Atlanta City Directory Co.|page=1392|via=[[Ancestry.com]]}} Strupper later became a general agent for the Volunteer State Life Insurance Company, and by 1948, he became the president of the Piedmont Life Insurance Co. based in Atlanta.{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/gtalumni/docs/1948_26_4/15 |title=Georgia Tech Alumni Magazine Vol. 26, No. 04 1948 by Georgia Tech Alumni Association |publisher=Issuu.com |date= |accessdate=2015-12-24}}{{cite book|title=Atlanta (Georgia) City Directory, 1948-49|year=1948|publisher=Atlanta City Directory Co.|page=1192|via=[[Ancestry.com]]}} Strupper died at his home in Atlanta's [[Georgian Terrace Hotel]] in February 1950 from [[thrombosis]]. He was age 57 at the time of his death. He was survived by a wife and a step-daughter, Gwyneth Oliver. He was buried in [[Columbus, Georgia]]. In 1972, the [[National Football Foundation]] named Strupper and nine others players who played before 1920 to the "Pioneer" section of the [[College Football Hall of Fame]].{{cite news|title=New-Found Fame|newspaper=Journal Courier, Jacksonville, Ill.|date=April 23, 1972|page=23|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/5270549/newfound_fame/}} He was also inducted into the Georgia Tech Athletics Hall of Fame in 1956 and the [[Georgia Sports Hall of Fame]] in 1974.{{cite web|title=Georgia Tech Athletics Hall of Fame|publisher=Georgia Institute of Technology|work=RamblinWreck.com|accessdate=May 15, 2016|url=http://www.ramblinwreck.com/ot/fame/halloffame.html#fbc}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gshf.org/pdf_files/inductees/gshf_inductee_list_sort_last_name.pdf |title=Member Georgia Sports Hall of Fame|publisher=Georgia Sports Hall of Fame |accessdate=May 15, 2016}} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=n}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{Cfbhof|1281|Everett Strupper}} * {{Find a Grave}} {{Navboxes | title = Everett Strupper—championships, awards, and honors | list1 = {{1917 Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football navbox}} {{1916 College Football Composite All-Southerns}} {{1917 College Football Consensus All-Americans}} {{1917 College Football Composite All-Southerns}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Strupper, Everett}} [[Category:1896 births]] [[Category:1950 deaths]] [[Category:American football halfbacks]] [[Category:Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football players]] [[Category:Mercer Bears football coaches]] [[Category:Oglethorpe Stormy Petrels football coaches]] [[Category:High school football coaches in the United States]] [[Category:All-American college football players]] [[Category:All-Southern college football players]] [[Category:College Football Hall of Fame inductees]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Atlanta]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Columbus, Georgia]] [[Category:Players of American football from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Deaths from thrombosis]]

[[Image:Seductive death EHLanglois.jpg|frame|'Seductive death' by [[Eustache-Hyacinthe Langlois]]]] '''Fascination with death''' has occurred throughout human history, characterized by obsessions with [[death]] and all things related to death and the [[afterlife]].
In past times, people would form cults around death and figures. Famously, [[Anubis]], [[Osiris]], [[Hades]], and [[La Santa Muerte]] have all had large cult followings. La Santa Muerte (Saint Death), or the personification of death, is currently worshiped by many in [[Mexico]] and other countries in [[Central America]]. [[Day of the Dead]] (2 November), is a celebration for the dead.
==History== The [[ancient Egyptians]] are most famous for their fascination of death by mummifying their dead and building exquisite tombs, like the [[pyramids of Giza]], for their dead. Many of their deities were death-related, such as: [[Ammut]], the devourer of unworthy souls; Anubis, the guardian of the [[Necropolis]] and the keeper of poisons, medicines, and herbs; and Osiris, the king of the dead.
The [[Greek underworld]], [[Hades]], was ruled by the god Hades, and had five rivers that flowed through it. The rivers were: [[Acheron]], river of sadness; [[Cocytus]], river of lamentation; [[Lethe]], river of forgetfulness; [[Phlegethon]], river of fire; [[Styx (mythology)|Styx]], river of hate. The Underworld had attendants who, though not rulers, were important gods and beings. The [[Furies]] were female spirits who exacted vengeance against people who committed specific crimes. [[Keres (mythology)|Keres]] were female spirits of death and destruction. [[Persephone]] was the goddess of the underworld and the spouse of Hades. [[Thanatos]], the god of death, was said to wear dark robes.
The [[Vikings]] believed that if a warrior died in battle, he would be taken to the Norse afterlife: the hall of [[Valhalla|Valhöll]], in which the warriors would prepare for [[Ragnarok|Ragnarökk]], the battle at the end of the world. [[Rune stones]] were erected to commemorate particularly brave warriors. Death in one's sleep (a "straw death") was considered dishonorable.
===Modern Western culture=== In the early part of the 20th century, it was common to hold [[séance]]s at dinner parties. A séance is an event where a group of people (3 or more) try to communicate with the dead through one person of the group, known as a [[psychic medium]].
This fascination with death in Western Culture can be observed in many of [[Walt Disney]]'s fairytales. After being responsible for the death of an owl on his family's farm when he was 7 years old, he was haunted by the experience and other influences of death in his life, leading to a strong correlation with death in his children's stories.
Today there are a number of authors who have spoken on the fascination people have with death. "If it bleeds, it leads" is a phrase related to this, meaning that in the [[mass media]] most of the material is based on death. For example: death and crime are almost always a topic in the news. The [[Goth subculture|goth]] and [[Metal subculture|metal]] subcultures are often associated with death and dying.
[[Daniel Kahneman]] and others have studied the psychology behind this. For example, people buy insurance and make other decisions based on what comes readily to mind—e.g., the previously recorded high-water mark for a flood, rarely considering that something worse is possible and in many cases eventually likely. This interacts with the management policies of media outlets to create [[availability cascade]]s and [[Media feeding frenzy|media feeding frenzies]]: For example, "[[stroke]]s cause almost twice as many deaths as all accidents combined, but 80% of respondents [in a survey] judged accidental death to be more likely. ... [This is because media] coverage is itself biased toward novelty and poignancy. The media do not just shape what the public is interested in, but also are shaped by it."<ref>{{Citation | last = Kahneman | first = Daniel | year = 2011 | title = Thinking, Fast and Slow | publisher = Farrar, Straus and Giroux | ISBN = 978-0374275631}}</ref>
This fascination with death and interaction with media editorial policies sometimes has problematic consequences for public policy. For example, Vincent Sacco<ref>{{Citation | last = Sacco | first = Vincent F. | date=May 1995 | title = Media Constructions of Crime | journal = Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science | volume = 539 | pages = 141–154}}, reprinted as chapter 2 of Potter and Kapeller (1998, pp. 37-51, esp. p. 42)</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Sacco|first1=Vincent F|title=When Crime Waves|date=2005|publisher=Sage|isbn=0761927832}}</ref> [[United States incarceration rate#Editorial policies of major media|and others]] described how the mainstream commercial media in the United States changed their editorial policies in the 1970s to focus more on the police blotter. The human psychology behind "If it bleeds, it leads" meant they could retain or even increase their audience while reducing the cost of producing the news: [[Investigative journalism]] is enormously expensive, especially if it offends a major advertiser. Focusing on crimes apparently committed by people without substantive political or economic power is cheap. The resulting increase in crime stories convinced the US electorate that crime was out of control. This led to the election of politicians who would "get tough on crime." The result was a five-fold increase in the [[United States incarceration rate]] not justified by any actual increase in crime.
==Necrophilia== '[[Necrophilia]]' is generally used in English to refer to the [[paraphilia]] associated with dead bodies, although the term has been used in a broader sense and in foreign language merely to refer to 'a fascination with death.'
