revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} {{infobox civilian attack | title = La Loche shootings | image = Dene High School.JPG | image_upright = 1.3 | caption = La Loche Community School's Dene Building | date = {{start date and age|2016|01|22}} | time = {{circa}} 1:00 p.m.{{spnd}}1:15 p.m. | timezone = [[Central Standard Time|CST]] | location = [[La Loche]], [[Saskatchewan]], Canada | coordinates = {{coord|56|29|58|N|109|27|11|W|region:CA-SK_type:landmark|display=inline}}
(Dene Crescent)
{{coord|56|29|18|N|109|26|43|W|region:CA-SK_type:edu|display=inline,title}}
(Dene Building) | type = [[Spree shooting]], [[school shooting]] | fatalities = 4 | injuries = 7 | verdict = [[Life imprisonment]] with no chance of [[parole]] for ten years. | susperp = Unidentified 17-year-old male (in custody) | weapons = [[Shotgun]] | motive=Reaction to [[school bullying]] (possibly) }} On January 22, 2016, four people were killed and seven others injured in a [[shooting spree]] in [[La Loche]], [[Saskatchewan]], Canada. Two boys, said to be the suspect's cousins, were killed at their home, and two teachers were killed at the Dene Building of the [[La Loche Community School]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/it-hurts-for-everybody-la-loche-residents-in-mourning-after-school-shooting/article28363770/ |title=Accused in La Loche shooting is related to two victims |work=The Globe and Mail |date=January 24, 2016 |accessdate=January 24, 2016 |first=Carrie |last=Tait}}{{cite news|url=http://www.calgarysun.com/2016/01/22/saskatchewan-school-under-lockdown|title='Right now, La Loche is devastated:' Saskatchewan school shooting leaves four dead|website=calgarysun.com|publisher=Calgary Sun|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|first=Jason|last=Warick}}{{cite news|title=Canada school shooting: Five killed in Saskatchewan|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-35388594?ns_mchannel=social&ns_campaign=bbc_breaking&ns_source=twitter&ns_linkname=news_central|website=bbc.com|publisher=BBC|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016}}{{cite news|title=La Loche, Sask., shooting death toll left 4 dead, RCMP say|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/la-loche-community-school-lock-down-jan22-1.3416143|website=cbc.ca|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016}} A 17-year-old male suspect was apprehended and placed into custody.{{cite news|url=http://thestarphoenix.com/news/local-news/right-now-la-loche-is-devastated-2|title='They were my best friends'; Grandfather of slain La Loche boys mourns (w/ video)|publisher=''[[The Star Phoenix]]''|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016|first=Jason|last=Warick}}{{cite news|last1=Martinez|first1=Michael|last2=Ellis|first2=Ralph|title=Four dead, several injured in shooting in Saskatchewan school|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/01/22/americas/saskatchewan-la-loche-school-shooting-canada/index.html|website=cnn.com|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016}} ==Shootings== [[File:La loche shooting.JPG|thumb|left|Dene Building on {{nowrap|January 24}}]] According to police, the shootings began at a residence in the 300 block of Dene Crescent, where the suspect shot two of his cousins some time before {{nowrap|1:00 p.m.}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/01/23/a-timeline-of-events-in-a-deadly-shooting-in-northern-saskatchewan_n_9062124.html|title=La Loche Shooting: A Timeline Of Events|website=huffingtonpost.ca|publisher=Huffington Post Canada|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016}}{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/five-dead-two-hurt-worst-canada-school-shooting-003409189.html|title=Four dead in worst Canada school shooting in decade, suspect caught|publisher=Yahoo! News|agency=Reuters|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|first=Rod|last=Nickel|first2=Julie|last2=Gordon}}{{cite news|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2473203/eye-witness-accounts-of-the-la-loche-school-shooting/|title=Eye-witness accounts of the La Loche school shooting|website=globalnews.ca|publisher=Global News|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016}} He then went to La Loche Community School's Dene Building{{efn|The Dene Building houses grades 7 through 12 and is sometimes referred to as Dene High School.{{cite news |first=Julia |last=Jacobo |title=4 Dead in Canada School Shooting, 2 Critically Injured |date=January 22, 2016 |accessdate=January 31, 2016 |website=ABC News |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/canadian-school-put-lockdown-amid-reports-shooting/story?id=36457082}}{{cite web |title=La Loche |date=n.d. |accessdate=January 31, 2016 |website=Northern Lights School Division No. 113 |url=http://www.nlsd113.com/Northen%20Lights%20School%20Division/La%20Loche}}}} and began firing at around 1:05, shortly before lunch ended,{{cite news|title=‘My school is a good school’: La Loche shooting survivor tells her story|url=https://www.rt.com/news/329874-laloche-shooting-survivor-interview/|website=rt.com|publisher=[[Russia Today]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016}} reportedly with a [[shotgun]].{{cite news |first=Jason |last=Markusoff |title=La Loche: A small town's grief. A nation's shame. |date=January 27, 2016 |accessdate=June 17, 2016 |website=Maclean's |url=http://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/la-loche-a-small-towns-grief-a-nations-shame/}}{{cite news |first=Douglas |last=Quan |title=Inside the deadly school shooting that shattered La Loche |date=January 28, 2016 |accessdate=January 29, 2016 |website=National Post |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/inside-the-deadly-school-shooting-that-shattered-la-loche}} He fired at least six or seven shots inside the building, killing a teacher and an assistant and wounding seven others. The school shooting lasted for about eight minutes. Between 1:08 and 1:10, a suspect with a gun was spotted by a responding officer, who chased him through the building and eventually arrested him outside at 1:15. Afterwards, police were notified of the bodies at the residence on Dene Crescent. Both the Dene Building and the elementary school were put on [[lockdown]] during the shooting.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/dead-la-loche-canada-school-shooting-article-1.2506479|title=Four dead in La Loche, Canada, school shooting; suspect in custody|work=The New York Daily News|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|first=Denis|last=Slattery}} The suspect reportedly posted his intentions on [[Facebook]].{{cite news|title=Alleged La Loche shooter sent 'chilling' chat messages about killing two people before heading to school|url=http://thestarphoenix.com/news/crime/la-loche-community-school-in-lockdown-stars-dispatched-we-will-not-be-allowing-anyone-in-or-out|publisher=[[Saskatoon Star Phoenix]]|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|first=Alex|last=MacPherson|first2=Morgan|last2=Modjeski|first3=Dave|last3=Deibert}}{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/la-loche-suspect-allegedly-killed-his-two-brothers-before-school-shooting-unconfirmed-reports|title=La Loche school shooting suspect allegedly posted intentions on Facebook: report|work=National Post|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016}} Of about 350 enrolled students, around 150 were at school at the time, since many had taken final exams that morning and had no further classes. ===Victims=== The deceased victims were identified as brothers Dayne, 17, and Drayden Fontaine, 13; and teachers Adam Wood, 35, and Marie Janvier, 21.{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/police-charge-17-year-old-boy-with-four-counts-of-first-degree-murder-in-la-loche-mass-shooting |title=Police charge 17-year-old boy with four counts of first-degree murder in La Loche mass shooting |publisher=''[[National Post]]'' |agency=[[The Canadian Press]] |date=January 23, 2016 |accessdate=January 23, 2016}} Janvier and the Fontaine brothers died at the scene, and Wood later died in the local hospital.{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/01/23/uxbridge-man-victim-of-saskatchewan-shooting.html |title=La Loche teen facing four first-degree murder counts in shooting spree|website=thestar.com |publisher=The Star |date=January 23, 2016 |accessdate=January 23, 2016 |first=Robin Levinson |last=King |first2=Ben |last2=Spurr}} Seven other people were injured.{{cite news |last=Gordon |first=Julie |last2=Nickel |first2=Rod |url=http://www.duluthnewstribune.com/news/3931594-remote-canadian-community-reels-shootings |title=Remote Canadian community reels from shootings |publisher=Duluth News Tribune |agency=Reuters |date=January 23, 2016 |accessdate=January 23, 2016}} The four most seriously wounded were flown to and hospitalized at [[Royal University Hospital]] in [[Saskatoon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/02/12/saskatchewan-government-says-one-la-loche-shooting-victim-released-from-hospital_n_9217408.html|title=La Loche Shooting Victim Released From Hospital|work=Huffington Post Canada|date=February 12, 2016|accessdate=February 17, 2016}} All were in critical condition two days after the shootings, according to an official in the Saskatchewan government. On {{nowrap|January 27}}, an official said three had been released.{{cite news |title=3 La Loche shooting victims released from hospital |date=January 27, 2016 |accessdate=January 27, 2016 |website=CBC News |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatoon/la-loche-shootings-three-victims-released-from-hospital-1.3422108}} A fourth was released on {{nowrap|February 12}}. ==Suspect== Police have not released the name of the suspect as he is protected by a [[publication ban]] per Canada's [[Youth Criminal Justice Act]]. They said he was a student at the school and that he is 17.{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/saskatchewan-community-in-shock-after-4-killed-in-mass-shooting-1.2749183|title=Saskatchewan community in shock after 4 killed in mass shooting|website=ctvnews.ca|publisher=CTV News|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016}} According to friends, he was bullied at school for his appearance.{{cite news |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/01/25/suspect-in-la-loche-shooting-was-bullied-a-loner-says-source-close-to-accused.html |title=Suspect in La Loche shooting was bullied, a loner, says source close to accused |website=Toronto Star |date=January 25, 2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2016}} ==Reactions and aftermath== [[File:La loche shooting Dene School 03.JPG|thumb|left|Media vehicles on La Loche Avenue]] [[Prime Minister of Canada|Canadian Prime Minister]] [[Justin Trudeau]], [[Premier of Saskatchewan|Saskatchewan Premier]] [[Brad Wall]], [[United States Ambassador to Canada|U.S. Ambassador to Canada]] [[Bruce Heyman]] and other Canadian politicians issued statements expressing their condolences and shock at the shooting.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/canada/12116707/Canada-school-shooting-La-Loche-school-in-lockdown-live.html|title=Canada school shooting: five killed at La Loche school - latest|website=telegraph.co.uk|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=January 22, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2016|first=Harriet|last=Alexander}}{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/la-loche-shooting-condolences-pour-in-for-victims-1.2749211|title=La Loche shooting: Condolences pour in for victims|website=ctvnews.ca|publisher=CTV News|date=January 23, 2016|accessdate=January 23, 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/saskatchewan-will-reach-out-to-u-s-officials-after-la-loche-shooting-wall-1.2749780|title=Saskatchewan will reach out to U.S. officials after La Loche shooting: Wall |work=CTV News |date=January 24, 2016 |accessdate=January 25, 2016}} Wall pledged counselling support and to cover costs for those travelling to see the hospitalized victims in Saskatoon. Kevin Janvier,{{efn|Marie Janvier's father was also named Kevin Janvier but was a different person.}} the acting mayor of La Loche, and [[Georgina Jolibois]], MP for the [[Desnethé—Missinippi—Churchill River]] electoral district, called to have the school torn down and rebuilt in light of the trauma caused by the shootings.{{cite news |author=CBC News staff |title=La Loche shooting: Mayor, local MP call for school to be 'torn down' |work=CBC News |date=January 24, 2016 |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/weather-temporarily-delays-brad-wall-visit-to-la-loche-following-shootings-1.3417814 |accessdate=January 24, 2016}} On {{nowrap|January 23}}, prior to a hockey game at the [[Air Canada Centre]], the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] and [[Montreal Canadiens]] had a [[minute of silence]] for the victims.{{cite web|url=http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=799393|title=Around the League notebook: Saturday, Jan. 23|work= National Hockey League|date=January 27, 2016|accessdate=January 27, 2016}} [[File:La Loche Community School.JPG|thumb|right|Flowers at the Dene Building]] RCMP Superintendent Grant St. Germaine called the incident the worst shooting tragedy in Canadian history at a high school or elementary school.{{cite news |first=Carrie |last=Tait |title=Two staff, two brothers named as Sask. school shooting victims |work=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=January 24, 2016 |accessdate=January 24, 2016 |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/two-school-staff-two-brothers-named-as-victims-in-saskatchewan-school-shooting/article28362794/}} [[Reuters]] reported that it was the worst Canadian school shooting since the [[École Polytechnique massacre]] of 1989, in which fourteen were killed.{{cite news |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/01/23/world/crime-legal-world/five-dead-two-critical-shootings-northern-saskatchewan/#.VqSyHxSJ_Z5 |title=Canada gunman kills four in worst shooting since '89 |website=[[The Japan Times]] |agency=Reuters |date=January 23, 2016 |accessdate=January 24, 2016}}{{efn|Four were killed and one wounded at the [[Concordia University massacre]] in 1992.}} Classes at La Loche Community School were suspended immediately after the shooting. On {{nowrap|January 26}}, the local school board, Northern Lights School Division No. 113, told parents the school would reopen in seven to ten more days, though the reopening was postponed to at least {{nowrap|February 22}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatoon/la-loche-community-school-to-remain-closed-1.3432711|title=La Loche Community School to remain closed|work=CBC News|date=February 3, 2016|accessdate=February 4, 2016}} Plans to tear down the school were considered, but not passed.{{cite web|url=http://saskatoon.ctvnews.ca/wall-says-la-loche-school-that-was-site-of-deadly-shooting-will-be-utilized-1.2771633|title=Wall says La Loche school that was site of deadly shooting will be utilized|work=CTV News|date=February 9, 2016|accessdate=February 9, 2016}} It said that it was willing to implement a security program at that time, following community discussion on what that should entail. In the meantime, the elementary school building remains open for students to gather, receive counselling, and play [[floor hockey]].{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Purdy |title=La Loche school could have security when classes resume after shooting |date=January 27, 2016 |accessdate=January 27, 2016 |publisher=Toronto Star |agency=Canadian Press |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/01/27/la-loche-school-could-have-security-when-classes-resume-after-shooting.html}} Exams for the first semester were cancelled for students who had not taken them on the morning of the shootings.{{cite web|url=https://m.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=977973552249285&id=515066148540030|title=La Loche Community School Facebook post|work=Facebook|date=January 26, 2016|accessdate=January 26, 2016}} On January 29, Trudeau and Wall visited La Loche, where the former met with community leaders. Earlier that morning, a moment of silence was held in schools located across Saskatchewan.{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2485895/trudeau-wall-head-to-la-loche-teachers-write-letter-to-students/|title=Trudeau arrives in La Loche after ‘heartbreaking’ school shooting|website=globalnews.ca|publisher=Global News|date=January 29, 2016|accessdate=January 29, 2016|first=David|last=Giles|first2=Doug|last2=Lett}} ==Legal proceedings== On {{nowrap|January 23}}, the suspect was charged with four counts of first-degree murder, seven counts of attempted murder, and one count of unauthorized possession of a firearm. Two days later, he was arraigned in a provincial court in [[Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan|Meadow Lake]], then remanded to a youth facility. As of August 2016, the suspect had appeared in court seven times and his next court date was scheduled for {{nowrap|October 28}}. Authorities have stated that they would like to sentence him as an adult if he is convicted.{{cite news |first=Colton |last=Swiderski |title=Accused in La Loche shooting elects trial by judge and jury |date=August 29, 2016 |accessdate=August 31, 2016 |website=Battlefords Now |location=North Battleford, Saskatchewan |url=http://battlefordsnow.com/article/530953/accused-la-loche-shooting-elects-trial-judge-and-jury}}{{cite news |first=Colton |last=Swiderksi |title=Court case for accused La Loche shooter adjourned |date=July 19, 2016 |accessdate=August 9, 2016 |website=Battlefords Now |location=North Battleford, Saskatchewan |url=http://battlefordsnow.com/article/525319/court-case-accused-la-loche-shooter-adjourned}} On October 28, 2016 the teen pleaded guilty to two counts of [[first-degree murder]], two counts of [[second-degree murder]] and seven counts of attempted murder.[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatoon/court-appearance-la-loche-shooting-oct28-1.3825928 Teen charged in deadly La Loche, Sask., shooting pleads guilty] On May 8, 2018, the gunman was sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] with no chance of [[parole]] for ten years.{{cite news|last1=Giles|first1=David|last2=Kessler|first2=Ryan|title=La Loche school shooter sentenced to life in prison|url=https://globalnews.ca/author/david-giles/|accessdate=May 19, 2018|agency=Global News|publisher=Corus Entertainment Inc.|date=May 8, 2018}} ==See also== * [[List of massacres in Canada]] * [[List of attacks related to secondary schools]] ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== by firearm in Saskatchewan]] [[Category:School shootings committed by minors]] [[Category:January 2016 crimes in North America]] [[Category:Mass shootings]] [[Category:Massacres in Canada]] {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Ludwig Becker Self Portrait (between 1850..1861) SmallFiltered.jpg|thumb|Ludwig Becker, by [[Frederick Schoenfeld]]]] '''Ludwig Becker''' (5 September 1808 – 29 April 1861) was a German artist, explorer and naturalist. He was born in [[Rödelheim]] near [[Frankfurt]] am Main. He moved to Australia in 1850, and was a member of the ill-fated [[Burke and Wills expedition]]. He died at the expedition's camp on the western bank of Koorliatto Waterhole, [[Bulloo River]] in 1861.
==Early years== Becker was born at [[Rödelheim]] near [[Frankfurt]] am Main, Germany, in 1808. He left Germany in 1850. As was common practice at the time, he was referred to as Dr. Becker, but had not studied at a university.
His father was Ernst Friedrich Becker (1750–1826) and his mother was Amöne Eleonore Weber (1782–1819). Becker was the eldest of five children from this marriage. After his mother's death, Becker's father married Johanette Christiane Weber, a younger sister of his first wife. They had three more children. # Ludwig Phillip Heinrich Becker (1808–1861) # Friedrich Christian Becker (1809–1875) # Karl Becker (1813–1850) # Heinrich Leonard Becker (1815–1871) # Bertha Becker (1817–1822) # August Becker (1821–1887) # Ferdinand Becker (1822–1913) # Ernst Becker (1826–1888)
==Australia== [[File:Ludwig Becker Bendigo 1853.jpg|thumb|''Bendigo'' by Ludwig Becker, 1853 watercolour]] After some time in England he travelled from [[Liverpool]] in November 1850 on the ship ''Hannah'' via [[Pernambuco|Pernambuco, Brazil]],<ref>Ludwig Becker – Letters, 1850–1855 to Dr. Kaup; in German with some English translations, Manuscripts in the Mitchell Library NSW, CY REEL 603, ML*D83</ref> and arrived in [[Launceston, Tasmania|Launceston]], [[Van Diemen's Land]] in early 1851. He was described by Lady [[William Denison|Denison]] as "one of those universal geniuses who can do anything ... a very good naturalist, geologist ... draws and plays and sings, conjures and ventriloquises and imitates the notes of birds so accurately". From 1852 until 1854, while mining for gold in [[Bendigo]], Becker made meteorological observations and produced sketches which he exhibited in Melbourne in April 1854. He became a council member of the Victorian Society of Fine Arts in 1856 and of the [[Royal Society of Victoria|Philosophical Institute of Victoria]] in 1859, and was a leading member of the German Club. He corresponded with [[ornithologist]] and [[zoologist]] [[John Gould]], known as the father of bird study in Australia, on the [[lyrebird]], and was one of the first to try to raise a lyrebird chick and sent sketches of the egg to ornithologists in Germany and France.
He illustrated botanical works for [[Ferdinand Mueller]] including ''[[Fragmenta phytographiae Australiae]]'' (1858–82) and ''The Plants Indigenous to the Colony of Victoria'' (1860–65).<ref>[http://www.anbg.gov.au/biography/becker-ludwig.html "Becker, Ludwig (1808–61)"], [[Australian National Herbarium]]</ref>
==Burke and Wills expedition== His scientific knowledge and artistic ability qualified him for selection as a member<ref>Anne Matthews: "Ludwig Becker, Artist and Scientist in the Desert", pp. 148ff; in: ''Sheena Coupe, Frontier Country – Australia's Outback Heritage'', Vol. 1, Willoughby: Weldon Russell (1989)</ref> of the Victorian Exploring Expedition in 1860–61, which has since become known as the [[Burke and Wills expedition]]. It was organised by the Philosophical Institute of Victoria which in 1860 became the [[Royal Society of Victoria]].
The Burke and Wills expedition was led by [[Robert O'Hara Burke]], a police superintendent in the [[Castlemaine, Victoria]] district. In 1860 he was given leave to take command of the exploring expedition to cross the continent from Melbourne in the south to the [[Gulf of Carpentaria]] in the north. The objectives of the expedition were hazy and its route, from [[Cooper Creek]] to the Gulf of Carpentaria, was decided less than a month before it set out. Burke's instructions, sent after him because they were not ready at the time, were lengthy and vague. The real object of the expedition appears to have been to snatch from the South Australian explorer, [[John McDouall Stuart]], the honour of making the first south-north crossing of the continent. Sir [[Henry Barkly]], Governor of Victoria 1856–1863, described it as "the glorious race across the continent between the expeditions fitted out in this and the adjacent colony of South Australia".
The Burke and Wills expedition was the most expensive in the history of Australian exploration.{{Citation needed|date=December 2013}} It cost over £60,000 and would eventually claim seven lives. The expedition was provided with more than two dozen camels, imported complete with [[Afghan (Australia)|cameleers]]. There were horses and wagons, food for two years and lavish equipment. The party consisted of five officers: Burke, Landells as second-in-command, and William John Wills, third-in-command and surveyor and meteorologist and the two German scientific officers: Becker and Hermann Beckler, medical officer and botanist. The expedition also included a foreman, nine assistants and the camel-drivers.
The expedition left Melbourne on 20 August 1860 and made progress through the settled districts of Victoria to [[Swan Hill]] and [[Balranald]] and reached [[Menindee]] on the [[Darling River]] at the beginning of October. Burke was in haste and left much of his provisions at Balranald and more at Menindee.<ref>{{cite book|last=Phoenix|first=Dave|title=Following Burke and Wills across Victoria: a touring guide|publisher=Phoenix|year=2011|isbn=9780646564197}}</ref>
Becker, as artist, naturalist and geologist on a salary of £300, received lengthy instructions from Doctor [[John Macadam]], honorary secretary of the Exploration Committee, which stipulated that he should collect specimens, keep a diary and produce daily maps with illustrations and sections. He sent his first dispatches from Swan Hill, and from Menindee sent a number of specimens. He became despondent when these were not acknowledged.
Burke became impatient with the time lost in making scientific investigations and ordered Becker and Beckler to cease their investigations and work like the rest of the men and walk instead of ride. In a report to the Exploration Committee, Landells wrote that Burke requested him not to allow Becker to ride and had observed that if Becker accompanied the expedition, and got through, people would say that it would not be difficult to cross to Carpentaria, and that he was to be walked until he gave in. At one stage Becker did not eat for three days and became faint. He had to wait until everyone was asleep to do his writing and sketching.
After quarrelling with Burke, Landells resigned at Menindee and Burke promoted Wills to second in command, replacing him as third officer by a local man, [[William Wright (explorer)|William Wright]], who proved incompetent and unreliable.
Burke's orders were that his base camp was to be at Cooper Creek; instead, he divided his party, transport and provisions, dashing on to Cooper Creek with an advance party and ordering Wright to follow with as little delay as possible. However, Wright waited in Menindee for three months – by which time Burke had travelled to the Gulf of Carpentaria and back – before transporting the vital reserve transport and provisions the 400 miles to Cooper Creek.
Becker was with Wright's party in Menindee. Frustrated by the lack of communication from the Exploration Committee, he no longer wrote his daily reports and concentrated instead on sketching. He became aware of the possible failure of the expedition, but his letter to the committee about the delays was ignored.
Wright's party moved north at the end of January 1861, and reached Torowoto Swamp, about halfway from Menindee to Cooper Creek on 12 February. By this time Becker and others were suffering from [[scurvy]] and the effects of bad water. At their camp at Rat Point, Becker and William Purcell, the cook, were very ill. Wright moved on to try to reach Cooper Creek, but only made it to Bulloo and returned. Beckler remained with the sick members, and on 8 April wrote to his brother of Becker's illness and the unlikelihood of his recovery, stating that, "I shall have to bury him here, and then what an outcry there will be for me in Melbourne!"
Wright wanted to send the sick men back to Menindee, but Beckler told him that they could not make a single day's journey. Wright then ordered the party on to Bulloo, which they reached on 21 April. Wright's party never continued onto Cooper Creek.
Meanwhile, Burke, impatient for Wright's arrival at Cooper Creek, selected Wills, King and Gray to accompany him to the gulf and left four men under the command of William Brahe, one of the assistants, at camp LXV at Cooper Creek. Burke decided to explore on foot and took provisions for twelve weeks and six camels and a horse as pack animals. It took four months to complete the 1500 miles, and Gray died before they returned to camp LXV at Cooper Creek. When Burke's party reached camp LXV on 21 April 1861, spent, starving and in rags, they found it deserted. Brahe's party, having given up hope of seeing Burke and Wills, had left that day for Menindee with six camels, twelve horses, all the clothes and most of the food. Burke decided that as they were in bad shape and had only two camels, they would not be able to catch Brahe's party and would not survive the 400-mile journey. He decided to make for [[Mount Hopeless (South Australia)|Mount Hopeless]], a 150-mile journey away, leaving a message of their intentions at camp LXV.
Brahe's party arrived at Wright's camp at Bulloo on 28 April. The natives were hostile, and had attacked the camp on 27 April. During this period, Becker was mostly unconscious and died on 29 April. He was buried near the graves of Purcell and Charles Stone who had died a few days earlier. The Commission of Enquiry into the causes of the deaths of Burke and Wills also found, from Dr Beckler's evidence, that Dr Becker died of [[dysentery]] and the exhaustion consequent upon it; of course with some peculiar symptoms, which were principally owing to the scurvy. After his burial, Becker's clothes, bedding and tent were burned and his other effects were placed in a pack for conveyance to Melbourne.
Becker had made meteorological observations daily until a month before he died. His death was lamented in newspapers and journals both in the Australian colonies and in Germany, and he was mourned by colleagues at the Royal Society. Governor [[Henry Barkly|Barkly]] paid tribute to "one of the earliest and most indefatigable contributors ... the name of Ludwig Becker will ... rank with those of [[Allan Cunningham (botanist)|Cunningham]], [[Edmund Kennedy|Kennedy]] and [[Ludwig Leichhardt|Leichhardt]] and the rest of that noble band who have sacrificed their lives in the cause of science." The City of [[Ballarat]] commemorated the expedition with a clock tower in 1863 referring to the deaths of "The Victorian Explorers Burke, Wills, Gray and Becker". The small Queensland parish of [http://www.geodata.us/australia_names_maps/aumaps.php?fid=134685&f=133&name=Becker Becker] perpetuates his name and some timber posts mark his grave.
==Legacy== This expedition paved the way for settlement in the area, with the first recorded settlement being [[Bulloo Downs Station|Bulloo Downs]] taken up by Jones, Sullivan and Molesworth Green in 1864.
Becker's papers were used as the basis for a novelization of his life, published in 2009.<ref>Martin Edmond; ''The Supply Party: Ludwig Becker on the Burke and Wills Expedition'', Glenside (Adelaide): East Street Publications 2009. {{ISBN|1-92103726-1}}</ref>
[[Dr Ludwig Becker's Grave]] is now listed on the [[Queensland Heritage Register]].<ref>{{cite QHR|16122|Dr Ludwig Becker's Grave|601359|accessdate=1 August 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Ludwig Becker (explorer)}} * [http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A030120b.htm Australian Dictionary of Biography] * [http://victoria.slv.vic.gov.au/burkeandwills/archives/views/beckers_sketchbook/becker1.html Becker's sketches from the Burke and Wills Expedition] * [http://www.burkeandwills.net.au/ Burke & Wills Web] A comprehensive website containing many of the historical documents relating to the Burke and Wills Expedition * [http://www.burkeandwills.org/ The Burke and Wills Historical Society] * [http://victoria.slv.vic.gov.au/burkeandwills/index.html Terra Incognita] Burke and Wills online exhibition at the State Library of Victoria * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070831175557/http://www.sciencevictoria.org.au/index1.htm The Royal Society of Victoria].
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox film | name = ''Magical Death'' | image = | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Napoleon Chagnon]] and [[Tim Asch]] | producer = | writer = | narrator = | starring = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = [[Documentary Educational Resources]] | released = 1973 | runtime = 29 min. | country = United States | language = English | budget = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Magical Death''''' is a documentary film by anthropologist [[Napoleon Chagnon]] that explores the role of the [[Shamanism|shaman]] within the [[Ya̧nomamö|Yanomamo]] culture, as well as the close relationship shamanism shares with politics within their society.
Chagnon and frequent collaborator [[Tim Asch]] allegedly disputed over the content of the film when Asch objected to its graphic depictions of the Yanomami engaging in symbolic death and cannibalism.<ref>http://www.salon.com/books/feature/2000/09/28/yanomamo/index.html</ref>
The film was awarded the American Film Festival Blue Ribbon.
{{Clear}}
==External links== * [https://www.jstor.org/pss/674159 'Reviewed by Eric Almquist in American Anthropologist Vol. 77, No. 1 (Mar., 1975), p. 179'] * [https://www.publicanthropology.net/e-book/download/yanomami-front-matter.pdf Reviewed on page 17 of Robert Borofsky's ''Yanomami: The fierce controversy and what we can learn from it'']
==References== <references/> * [http://www.salon.com/books/feature/2000/09/28/yanomamo/index.html ''Macho Anthropology'', an article written by Juno Gregory for Salon.com that discusses the filmmakers' differences over the film.]
[[Category:1973 films]] [[Category:Yanomami in film]] [[Category:Anthropology documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about death]]
{{Documentary-film-stub}}

{{autobiography|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Marios Kyriazis | image = Dr Marios Kyriazis.JPG | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1956|3|11|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Larnaca]], Cyprus | residence = [[London]], England, and [[Mioglia]], Italy | nationality = British, Greek Cypriot | known_for = Work in [[Life Extension]] | occupation = Anti-aging Physician and Biogerontologist | years_active = 30 | website = http://www.elpistheory.info }} '''Marios Kyriazis''' ({{lang-el|Μάριος Κυριαζής}}) (born 11 March 1956) is a medical [[Physician|doctor]] and [[gerontologist]]. He is known for work, publications and involvement with [[life extension]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/lifestyle/wellbeing/diet/8822879/Has-the-fountain-of-youth-been-found.html|title=Has the fountain of youth been found?|last=Llewellyn-Smith|first=Julia|date=2011-10-25|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-07-18|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
Applying the concept of [[hormesis]] on anti-ageing medicine, Kyriazis controversially suggested that leading a stressful, irregular and constantly stimulating lifestyle may be a way of reducing the impact of age-related dysfunction.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/get-stressed-stay-young-the-new-health-advice-vmcbgvmrl7p|title=Get stressed, stay young; the new health advice|last=Templeton|first=Sarah-Kate|date=2005-05-08|work=The Sunday Times|access-date=2018-07-17|language=en|issn=0956-1382}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/rest-of-world/Little-stress-a-day-keeps-the-doc-away/articleshow/1102355.cms|title=Little stress a day keeps the doc away - Times of India|work=The Times of India|date=May 7, 2005|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/lifestyle/health/anti-ageing-experts-share-their-secrets-2033328|title=Anti-ageing experts share their secrets|work=IOL Lifestyle|last=Coleman|first=Claire|date=12 June 2016|access-date=2018-07-18|language=en}}</ref>
==Medical history==
In 1996 Kyriazis founded the Historical Medical Equipment Society,{{cn|date=June 2018}} which aims to study old medical instruments related to the history of medicine in the UK.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hmes.org.uk |year=2009 |title=Introduction |author=Staff writer |website=Historical Medical Equipment Society |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110817231441/http://hmes.org.uk/ |archive-date=17 August 2011 |dead-url=yes}}</ref>The first public lecture was given at the [[University of London]] with support from the [[Wellcome Trust]]. As of July 2018, the society is no longer in existence.
In 2001, in association with the [[Larnaca]] Municipality, he organised an exhibition on the medical history in Cyprus with the theme "Medicine in Ancient Kition and Old Larnaca",{{cn|date=June 2018}} accompanied by a book on the matter with the same title.<ref name="Kyriazēs2001">{{cite book|last=Kyriazēs|first=Marios|title=Medicine in ancient Kition and old Larnaca|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T--LngEACAAJ|year=2001|publisher=Dēmos Larnakas|isbn=978-9963-603-24-4}}</ref>
Following the tradition of other [[Benefactor (law)|benefactors]] in the family (such as his grandfather Dr [[Neoclis Kyriazis]] and his great- uncle [[Damianos Kyriazis]]), in 2008 he founded the [[Kyriazis Medical Museum]], a cultural [[charitable foundation]] aiming to safe keep old medical items and traditions of [[Cyprus]], and to educate the public on the [[Cypriot Medical History]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/kyriazis-medical-museum|title=Kyriazis Medical Museum in Cyprus|website=Atlas Obscura|language=en|access-date=2018-07-19}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Anti-aging movement]] *[[Biological Immortality]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.thebls.org The British Longevity Society] * [http://www.elpisfil.org The ELPIS Foundation for Indefinite Lifespans website]
{{Life extension}}
